message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by silencing in the imprinting region of the paternal chromosome 15. This leads to the loss of expression of certain genes, resulting in symptoms such as poor muscle tone, feeding difficulties, and delayed development. Heteroplasmy is a mitochondrial phenomenon where cells contain a mixture of normal and mutated mitochondria. Anticipation refers to genetic disorders where the symptoms worsen with each generation. Incomplete penetrance refers to genetic disorders where some individuals with the gene mutation do not exhibit any symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by genetic changes on chromosome 15, specifically a lack of expression of genes on the paternal copy of chromosome 15. This is due to a phenomenon called imprinting, where certain genes are only expressed from one parent. In most cases of Prader-Willi syndrome, the paternal copy of chromosome 15 is deleted or otherwise silenced in the imprinting region. Therefore, the correct answer is (B), silencing in imprinting region.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a paternal deletion of chromosome 15q11-q13 or maternal uniparental disomy. This results in the silencing of imprinted genes in the region and leads to the symptoms observed in the patient. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) silencing in imprinting region. Heteroplasmy refers to the presence of different versions of mitochondrial DNA in a single cell or individual, anticipation is a phenomenon where genetic diseases become more severe or appear at an earlier age in subsequent generations, and incomplete penetrance refers to cases where individuals with a genetic mutation do not express the associated phenotype.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a deletion or abnormality in chromosome 15 in the imprinting region. This silencing of imprinted genes is the most common mechanism for the development of this condition. Heteroplasmy refers to the presence of two or more genetically distinct mitochondrial DNA types in the same individual. Anticipation describes a genetic phenomenon in which the severity or age of onset of a disease increases in successive generations. Incomplete penetrance refers to the situation in which not all individuals carrying a disease-associated genotype express the disease phenotype. None of these mechanisms are applicable to the development of Prader-Willi syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by silencing or deletion of paternal genes in the region 15q11-15q13. This occurs due to genomic imprinting in which certain genes are silenced based on which parent they are inherited from. Option A, heteroplasmy, refers to the presence of both normal and abnormal mitochondrial DNA within a single cell or individual, and is not associated with Prader-Willi syndrome. Option C, anticipation, refers to the phenomenon in which a genetic disorder becomes more severe and/or presents at an earlier age in successive generations, and is not associated with Prader-Willi syndrome. Option D, incomplete penetrance, refers to the presence of a genetic mutation that does not always result in the manifestation of the associated disease, and is not associated with Prader-Willi syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by silencing in the imprinting region of chromosome 15, which leads to the loss of expression of certain genes. This mechanism occurs in about 70% of cases. Heteroplasmy is a mechanism involved in mitochondrial diseases, anticipation is seen in some genetic disorders with increasing severity in subsequent generations, and incomplete penetrance occurs when individuals with a disease-causing gene variant do not show symptoms of the disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a lack of expression of paternal genes due to deletion or abnormality of the chromosome 15q11.2-q13 region. This region is subject to imprinting, where certain genes are only expressed from the maternal or paternal allele. In Prader-Willi syndrome, the paternal allele is silenced or deleted, leading to the characteristic symptoms. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) silencing in imprinting region. Heteroplasmy is a term used in mitochondrial DNA inheritance, anticipation refers to genetic disorders worsening or appearing earlier in subsequent generations, and incomplete penetrance refers to genetic disorders where not all individuals with the causative mutation will display the clinical symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by silencing in the imprinting region of chromosome 15. Heteroplasmy is a phenomenon involving mitochondria, and incomplete penetrance and anticipation are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by loss of function of genes on chromosome 15 due to a deletion, uniparental disomy, or an imprinting defect. Silencing in the imprinting region is the most common mechanism, occurring in about 70% of cases. This results in loss of expression of paternal genes on chromosome 15, leading to the characteristic features of the syndrome. Heteroplasmy refers to the presence of varying levels of abnormal mitochondrial DNA in different cells, which is not relevant to this condition. Anticipation refers to the phenomenon of symptoms worsening and/or appearing earlier in successive generations due to the expansion of trinucleotide repeats, which is seen in some genetic conditions but not in Prader-Willi syndrome. Incomplete penetrance refers to the presence of a genetic mutation that does not always result in clinical manifestations, which is also not relevant to this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by silencing of certain genes in the imprinting region on the chromosomes inherited from the father. This results in a variety of symptoms including feeding difficulties, poor muscle tone, and developmental delays. Heteroplasmy, anticipation, and incomplete penetrance are not associated with Prader-Willi syndrome.
